evidence_passages.title: The Competition
evidence_passages.text: Elena's hands trembled as she gripped her violin bow. She had practiced this piece for six months, sacrificing weekends and missing her best friend's birthday party. Now, standing on stage, she could see her parents in the front row—her father who had driven her to every lesson, her mother who had worked extra shifts to pay for the instrument. When she began to play, the notes flowed like water. For those three minutes, nothing else existed.
evidence_passages.question: What evidence shows that Elena is dedicated to violin?
evidence_pieces: practiced this piece for six months
missing her best friend's birthday party

evidence_passages.title: The Storm Shelter
evidence_passages.text: The tornado warning came at 2 PM. By 2:05, the Ortiz family was in their basement shelter—supplies stocked, radio ready, flashlights working. They had practiced this drill dozens of times since moving to Oklahoma. When the power went out and the roar grew louder, no one panicked. Mrs. Ortiz counted heads, Mr. Ortiz monitored the radio, and the kids played cards by flashlight, just as they had rehearsed.
evidence_passages.question: How do you know the Ortiz family was well-prepared?
evidence_pieces: By 2:05, the family was in their basement shelter
supplies stocked, radio ready, flashlights working
practiced this drill dozens of times

theme_analysis.title: The Weight of Words
theme_analysis.text: When Marcus first heard the rumor about himself, he laughed it off. But the whispers grew louder. Friends stopped sitting with him. His jokes fell flat in silent rooms. By week two, Marcus understood how words—even untrue ones—could isolate a person completely. When the truth finally came out, the apologizes felt hollow. Some damage, Marcus learned, couldn't be undone with 'sorry.'
theme_analysis.theme: Words have lasting power and consequences
development_stages: Beginning: Marcus dismisses the rumor as unimportant
Middle: He experiences the real effects—isolation, silence
Climax: He realizes the full impact of others' words
End: Even after truth emerges, the damage remains

theme_analysis.title: The Long Walk
theme_analysis.text: Day one of the charity walk, Priya focused on her blistered feet. Day two, she focused on the heat. Day three, she focused on her exhaustion. But by day four, she noticed the families cheering them on—families who would receive clean water because of this walk. Day five, her feet still hurt, but she barely noticed. She was too busy thinking about the wells her steps would build.
theme_analysis.theme: Perspective changes when we focus on purpose over discomfort
development_stages: Day 4: Shift to awareness of impact on others
Day 5: Personal pain becomes insignificant compared to purpose

development_passages.title: The Project Partners
development_passages.text: At first, Aisha resented being paired with Derek, the class clown who never took anything seriously. But when she saw his sketchbook—filled with detailed scientific drawings—she realized she had misjudged him. His humor, she learned, was armor. Underneath was someone as anxious about grades as she was. Together, they created a project that was both brilliantly researched and creatively presented. Neither could have done it alone.

central_idea_passages.title: The Teenage Brain
central_idea_passages.text: The teenage brain is not a broken adult brain—it's a brain optimized for learning and adaptation. The prefrontal cortex, responsible for decision-making, isn't fully developed until age 25. This explains why teens take risks: their brains are wired to explore and experiment. Meanwhile, the limbic system, which processes emotions, is highly active. This combination of underdeveloped judgment and heightened emotions creates the stereotypical teenage experience. Understanding this biology helps adults support teens rather than simply punish them for 'poor decisions.'
central_idea_passages.central_idea: The teenage brain is uniquely structured for learning, not flawed
development: Introduces reframing: not broken, but optimized
Explains biological basis: prefrontal cortex development
Connects to behavior: risk-taking has a purpose
Concludes with implication: changes how we should treat teens

argument_evaluation.title: Homework Debate
argument_evaluation.argument: Homework should be banned because students are stressed and studies show that excessive homework doesn't improve learning. In countries like Finland, students have minimal homework yet outperform American students on international tests. If homework worked, we would see better results from the hours students currently spend.
claims: Students are stressed (supported by widespread reports)
Excessive homework doesn't improve learning (needs citation)
Finland example (relevant, but may have other factors)
If homework worked, we'd see results (logical, but oversimplified)
argument_evaluation.evaluation: The argument makes valid points but relies partly on correlation without proving causation. Finland's success may involve other factors like teacher training and class size.
argument_evaluation.strength: Uses international comparison and acknowledges research
argument_evaluation.weakness: Doesn't address what amount of homework might be beneficial; generalizes from one country
